description.narrative: Coastal Afforestration - Community-based Adaptation to Climate Change through Coastal Afforestation in Bangladesh

description.narrative:
Objective
Reduce vulnerability of coastal communities to the impacts of climate change-induced risks in four upazilas in the coastal districts of Barguna and Patuakhali (Western Region), Bhola (Central Region), Noakhali (Central Region), and Chittagong (Eastern Region)

comment.narrative:
Coastal communities face climate change risks largely due to lack of adaptive capacity
Recent scientific findings project 15% increases in salinity, cyclonic events, and inundation of coastal areas, with up to 35 million people becoming climate refugees from the coastal areas by 2050

By the end of the project, over 80%0f households in project communities are able to anticipate climate risks and select the most effective risk reduction options. By the end of the project, at least 75% MoL and MoEF government officials and coastal management planners in target districts are able to identify climate induced risks in coastal areas and are capable of prioritizing planning and implementing effective adaptation measures with the involvement of communities

Incorporation of additional funding enriched the project outcome in reducing the vulnerability of coastal communities to the impacts of climate change induced risks through additional output activities with additional targets.
The project achieved both original and additional targets. Thus, the project has been able to enhance the resilience of protective ecosystem as well as contributed in reducing vulnerabilities in four upazilas viz. Anwara, Hatiya, Char Fassion and Barguna Sadar upazila.
N/A

description.narrative: Outcome 1 Enhanced Resilience of Vulnerable Coastal Communities and Protective Systems to Climate Risks

Percentage of satisfactory performance of the afforestation (plantation survival and growth) and livelihood measures (increased food security, incomes and income diversification) of the project beneficiaries (per RTPP)

comment.narrative:
Pre-project status of coastal landscapes being treated, and food/income status of project beneficiary households being assisted with livelihoods development (as drawn from the Participatory Assessments and Site Management Plan).
*To be noted that the changes in baseline and target at outcome level as per MTE (Mid Term Evaluation) have been incorporated in the revised and approved project document.

90% of the afforestation areas are assessed as effective and sustainable in post-plantation surveys
80% of the households participating in the project have increased food security and income to adapt to climate risks.
*As per MTE.

Development objective in reducing the vulnerability of coastal communities has been achieved completely.
>100% of the households participating in the project have increased their coping ability to the impacts of climate induced risks well as resilience of protective ecosystems enhanced through implementing 100% of plantation targets.

description.narrative: Outcome 2 Climate Risk Reduction Measures Incorporated into Coastal Area Management Frameworks

Percentage of unions, upazillas and districts in the project sites that have identified risk pertaining to CC and prepared strategy and action plans through participatory process to address the risks.

comment.narrative: No mechanisms and budgets available to local authorities to address climate change risks.* As per MTE

75% of local authorities in the project sites have adopted or strengthened plans and strategies to address climate change
50% of the local authorities are implementing afforestation and livelihood support measures in the inundation zone (between coastal forest and embankment)

> 90% of local authorities at union, upazila and district level in the project sites have adopted or strengthened plans and strategies to address CC risks and more than 80% of local authorities are able to identify climate risks and implement adaptation strategies and action plans through participatory process.
N/A

description.narrative: Outcome 3 National Policies Revised to Increase Climate Risk Resilience of Coastal Communities
Specific policies have been adopted in support of the projectâ€™s adaptation measures.( It was incorporated as per Mid-Term Evaluation Report, pl. see p.40 of MTR

comment.narrative: Currently there is a national coastal management policy and land use policy, in addition to several others that affect coastal development; however, they do not address climate change and adaptation issues in an integrated manner
Policies are adopted to support designation of land for community-based reclamation, model plantation practices and the implementation of co-management processes. * As per MTE

With a view to incorporate climate risk resilience issues in the national policies, the project team developed climate resilient policy recommendations for National Forest Policy (1994); National Land Use Policy ( 2001); National Coastal Zone Management Policy ( 2005) & National Environment Policy ( 1992) through gap analysis of existing policies which are highly relevant to the management of coastal Bangladesh in an integrated manner. Landless communities are now empowered with land ownership rights by accessing government lands.
N/A

description.narrative: Outcome 4 Learning, Evaluation, and Adaptive Management Enhanced
Number of proposals, papers, and other documents that incorporate learning from the project

comment.narrative: Development projects currently do not systematically benefit from learning practices and project lessons on community-based adaptation.

Adaptation measures piloted by the project are consistently modified and/or further improved, based on project experiences
All of the local authorities in the vicinity of the project sites have implemented some of the piloted adaptation measures outside of the project sites. * As per MTE

The project published 10 knowledge products; 17 Training Manuals, 2 Brochures and 7 Leaflets/Fact Sheets. More (5-10 nos.) scientific publications are also expected from Khulna University and Science & Technology University of Patuakhali, Bangladesh. The project prepared 4 documentary films. Project achievements highlighted both nationally and internationally and got wide electronic media coverage (6 coverage) in different TV channels and 7 national as well as 5 international print media coverage. Apart from this, 9 GOB officials participated in one international conference held in Malaysia and 11 participated in one (study tour to Laos, In addition, 16 participants took part in different conferences and workshops, held at Dhaka. Besides, 2 National Dialogues and 33 Lesson Sharing Dialogues at sub-national level with the participation of 457 GOB officials are also important learning components of the project (Please see the List of Activities of CBACC-CF project in Communicating part of this PIR). The exposure visits and lesson sharing dialogues contributed to the adaptation measures piloted by the project, which are consistently improved and modified. It is expected that these modified and improved adaptation measures will get large scale implementation in the follow up project to be implemented in 9 more coastal sites, for which the prodoc has already been signed by the UNDP and Economic Relations Division of Ministry of Planning, Bangladesh.
N/A

comment.narrative: There are no new policies to encourage EE practices and technologies and no ongoing efforts to harmonize â€œBrick Burning Actâ€? administrative procedures.
